At the emergency room 42 assessment, the lady had no fever with normal oxygen saturation. Obstetrical ultrasound was 43 normal. We performed lung ultrasound which showed pleural thickening and diffuse coalescent B-44 lines involving both lungs. The patient underwent a nasopharyngeal swab for COVID-19, and was 45 admitted to our hospital. The swab was positive for COVID-19. During the following four days of 46 admission, the woman showed no symptoms, normal oxygen saturation. A repeat LUS was 47 performed, which showed improvement of the ultrasonographic aspect with thinning of the pleura 48 and only some thin B-lines. The woman was discharged. She is now 29 weeks, asymptomatic, with 49 normally progressing pregnancy. 50

COVID-19 infection is classically diagnosed by real time reverse transcription polymerase 21 chain reaction and radiological investigations (X-ray or high-resolution computerized tomography). 22 These techniques are not without limitations. Ultrasound has been suggested as a reliable and 23 accurate tool for assessing the lungs in patients with suspected pneumonia. Obstetricians and 24 gynecologists are usually familiar with the use of ultrasound. Lung ultrasound can show specific 25 signs of interstitial pneumonia, which is characteristic of COVID-19 pulmonary infection.
